citation.article-title: Fusobacterium periodonticum, a new species from the human oral cavity.

p.s: Description of Fusobacterium peridonticum sp. nov.
Fusobacterium peridonticum (Pe. ri. o'don. ti. cum. Gr.n. peri around + odon, odontos tooth; M.L. neutr. adj. periodontium)
The fusiform bacteria of the human oral cavity have undergone considerable taxonomic re-arrangements since the first description of these organisms.

The oral fusiforms were divided by Knorr into three species (Fusobacterium nucleatum, Fusobacterium polymorphum, and Fusobacterium plauti-vincenti); by Slanetz and Rettger into four morphological and biochemical types; by Hine and Berry into three species (Fusiformis nucleatum, Fusiformis polymorphum, and Fusiformis dentium); by Spaulding and Rettger into two major biochemical and serological groups; and by BÏ•e into two genera (Fusobacterium and Leptotrichia). F. polymorphum and F. nucleatum have been consolidated into the latter species, which also includes organisms previously described as Fusiformis fusiformis.
Oral fusiforms have recently been identified which were not members of the genus Fusobacterium, but belonged to the genera Capnocytophaga and Bacteroides.

The definition of the genus Fusobacterium was, in the early 1970's, amended to include anaerobic, gram-negative, non-sporing rods which produce major amounts of butyric acid and do not produce isobutyric and isovaleric acids.
The isolates examined in this study fulfilled these criteria and were accordingly true strains of Fusobacterium.
The DNA-DNA homology studies showed from 6% to 40% relatedness between F. periodonticum and type strains of fusobacterial species which are biochemically related.
It is generally accepted that groups of bacteria which demonstrate less than 60% homology should be considered for classification as separate species.
Using this criterion, the homology data indicated that F. periodonticum was a new species.

The relatively high amount of C i17:0 and low amount of C n16:0 in F. periodonticum, especially when compared with the type strain of the common oral species F. nucleatum, indicated that F. periodonticum has additional properties which distinguish it from other fusobacterial species.
However, human oral strains of F. nucleatum can vary in their content of cellular fatty acids, a finding which may limit the taxonomic implications of the present cellular fatty acid data.
A small number of biochemical tests appears to be capable of distinguishing F. periodonticum from current Fusobacterium species.

Unlike F. periodonticum, the two reference strains of F. nucleatum used in this study do not ferment galactose: They only lower the pH values in fructose and glucose broths from 0.2 to 0.7 U, and exhibit no hydrolysis of hippurate. F. simiae, in contrast to F. periodonticum, does not ferment galactose, utilizes lactate, and is able to grow in 2% oxgall. F. gonidiaformans and F. varium produce abundant gas in deep glucose agar, F. naviforme does not form propionate from threonine, F. glutinosum ferments lactose, F. glutinosum utilizes lactate, and Fusobacterium aquatile hydrolyzes esculin - characteristics which distinguish these species from F. periodonticum.

Other known fusobacterial species, including Fusobacterium necrogenes, Fusobacterium perfoetens, Fusobacterium prausnitzii, F. plauti, Fusobacterium bullosum, and F. russii, differ from F. periodonticum by their inability to produce indole.
Oral fusobacteria which ferment fructose, galactose, and glucose have previously been isolated by Spaulding and Rettgert and Baird-Parker.
According to the biochemical descriptions, these authors' isolates differed somewhat from F. periodonticum.
However, unavailability of the previous isolates prevents establishment of any definitive relationship between these organisms and F. periodonticum.
We have only a very limited amount of information on the incidence of F. periodonticum in the human oral cavity and at non-oral sites.
Also, the clinical importance of this organism is not known.
The isolation of F. periodonticum from severe periodontitis lesions in a juvenile diabetes patient, however, may suggest that the organism possesses pathogenic potential.
The type strain of F. periodonticum is EK1-15 [American Type Culture Collection (ATCC) strain 33693].
